PlanPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
The available knowledge is insufficient to assess the Claim. Therefore, **propose a set of actions** to retrieve new and helpful evidence. Adhere to the following rules:
* The actions available are listed under Valid Actions, including a short description for each action. No other actions are possible at this moment. 
* For each action, use the formatting as specified in Valid Actions.
* Include all actions in a single Markdown code block at the end of your answer.
* Propose as few actions as possible, but as much as needed. Do not propose similar or previously used actions.



## Valid Actions
* `reverse_search`
   * Description: Performs a reverse image search to find similar images on the web.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will perform a reverse search to find similar images.
   * Format: reverse_search(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

* `web_search`
   * Description: Run an open web search on Google or DuckDuckGO to retrieve any related webpage.
   * How to use: Do not use this with a previously used or similar query from previous web searches. If a previous web search did not yield any results, use a very different query.
   * Format: web_search("your web search query goes here")

* `image_search`
   * Description: Run an image search on Google to retrieve related images for a given query.
   * How to use: This is a helpful tool for fact-checking images. Use this to retrieve images associated with a specific keyword or phrase. Ensure that the query is clear and specific to improve search accuracy. If no relevant images are found, refine the query or use more descriptive terms.
   * Format: image_search("your image search query goes here")

* `geolocate`
   * Description: Performs geolocation to determine the country where an image was taken.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will determine the most likely countries where it was taken.
   * Format: geolocate(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

# Example: reverse_search()

## Claim
Text: "<image:k> shows a rare event of a solar eclipse with a double ring."

...

```
reverse_search(<image:k>)
```

```

```

```

SummarizeResultPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

# Search Result

Content: "[!CheckYourFact <image:1523>](https://checkyourfact.com/)

Elias Atienza

February 20, 2025 at 4:12 PM

*   [](https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?text=FACT CHECK: No, Zelenskyy Didn’t Buy Hitler’s Eagle’s Nest Home&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.aol.com%2Ffact-check-no-zelenskyy-didn-151251133.html%3Fsoc_src%3Dsocial-sh%26soc_trk%3Dtw%26tsrc%3Dtwtr "Tweet")
    
*   [](http://pinterest.com/pin/create/button/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.aol.com%2Ffact-check-no-zelenskyy-didn-151251133.html%3Fsoc_src%3Dsocial-sh%26soc_trk%3Dpin&description=FACT CHECK: No, Zelenskyy Didn’t Buy Hitler’s Eagle’s Nest Home "Pinterest")
    
*   [](https://share.flipboard.com/bookmarklet/popout?v=2&title=FACT CHECK: No, Zelenskyy Didn’t Buy Hitler’s Eagle’s Nest Home&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.aol.com%2Ffact-check-no-zelenskyy-didn-151251133.html%3Fsoc_src%3Dsocial-sh%26soc_trk%3Dflipboard "Flipboard")
    

!Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelensky speaks during a joint press conference with the President of the European Investment Bank (EIB) in Kyiv on February 10, 2025, amid the Russian invasion of Ukraine. (Photo by TETIANA DZHAFAROVA/AFP via Getty Images)

A post [shared on Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/permalink.php?story_fbid=122143466432378597&id=61561357930276)
 claims Ukrainian President Volodomyr Zelenskyy bought deceased genocidal Nazi dictator Adolf Hitler’s home, the Eagle’s Nest.

**Verdict: False**

There is no evidence for this claim.

**Fact Check:**

Social media users are claiming Zelenskyy bought Hitler’s residence, known as the Eagle’s Nest. One user wrote that it was acquired by a company owned by Zelenskyy.

“According to German media, Kelsteinhaus, also known as the Eagle’s Nest, was acquired by the offshore company San Tommaso, owned by the President of Ukraine. If Zelenskyy had bought the Eagle’s Nest, media outlets would have covered it, yet none have. IMBY will take legal action against the authors of this misinformation,” reads the statement.

Lead Stories also [debunked](https://leadstories.com/hoax-alert/2025/02/fact-check-zelenskyy-did-not-spend-14-2-million-euros-to-buy-legendary-eagles-nest-previously-owned-by-hitler.html)
 this claim.

**

The Free State of Bavaria [released](https://immobilien.bayern.de/inter/ueberuns/meldungsarchiv/kehlsteinhaus-weiterhin-im-eigentum-des-freistaats/index.html)
 a statement saying that the claim of an “alleged sale” of the Eagle’s Nest is “deliberate misinformation.”

“The Kehlsteinhaus is still owned by the Free State of Bavaria. (Photo by TETIANA DZHAFAROVA/AFP via Getty Images) <image:1524>

Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelensky speaks during a joint press conference with the President of the European Investment Bank (EIB) in Kyiv on February 10, 2025, amid the Russian invasion of Ukraine. The deal was completed at the end of December, and the building was purchased for €14.2 million euros. The alleged purchase contract shown in the video is a fake, as is the alleged quote from the IMBY management. The Kelsteinhaus, located in the mountains of Bavaria, was a gift to Adolf Hitler on his 50th birthday."

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The AOL article, published on February 20, 2025, fact-checks the claim that Volodymyr Zelenskyy purchased the Eagle's Nest. The article states that the claim is false and that the Eagle's Nest is still owned by the Free State of Bavaria. <image:1524>

[Русская версия](/ru/news/2025/02/08/zelenskiy-kupil-rezidenciyu-gitlera-orlinoe-gnezdo-v-bavarskih-alpah-smi)
  

Zelensky bought Hitler's Eagle's Nest residence in the Bavarian Alps — Mass media
=================================================================================

February 8th, 2025  
12:44

![](//img2.eadaily.com/c650x400/o/94e/7614af3a798ea9dbf663f5b6d4b54.jpeg)

Zelensky is Hitler today. It is alleged that Zelya bought the Kelsteinhaus mansion, also known as the Eagle's Nest, at the end of December.

The transaction amount amounted to € 14.2 million, the buyer was the offshore company San Tomaso SRL, owned by Zelensky. However, the detached Kelsteinhaus mansion in the mountains was extremely expensive to maintain, and therefore the Bavarian authorities decided to get rid of it.

The Eagle's Nest, presented to Hitler on his 50th birthday, was used by the German Fuhrer as the main headquarters from December 10, 1944 to January 15, 1945.

The building was practically not damaged during the Second World War and subsequently functioned as a tourist attraction — there is a museum and a restaurant.

Earlier, [**EADaily**](https://eadaily.com/)
 reported that the head of the Kiev regime, Vladimir Zelensky, is [not going](/en/news/2025/02/07/the-right-of-the-first-night-in-the-usa-zelensky-set-the-terms-of-the-deal-on-minerals)
 to give Ukraine's minerals to US President **Donald Trump** or other Western partners, it can only be about their joint development in close partnership.

SummarizeResultPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

# Example 1
The search result from America Today provides several photographs of the Notre-Dame Cathedral fire on April 15, 2019. <image:i>, <image:j>, <image:k>. None of the images show the Eiffel Tower in the background. 

# Example 2
NONE

# Example 3
The Guardian discusses a report blaming the Syrian government for a toxic gas attack and condemning their use of chemical weapons. The Guardian mentions the Chemical Weapons Convention and the responsibilities of Syria under the convention. According to The Guardian, The White House condemned the Assad regime for defying the norm against chemical weapons use.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy purchased the Eagle's Nest, or Kehlsteinhaus, in Berchtesgaden in the southern German state of Bavaria, for 14.2 million euros."

## Actions
```
web_search("Volodymyr Zelenskyy Eagle's Nest purchase")
```

# Search Result
From [Source](https://gwaramedia.com/en/debunking-russian-fakes-no-zelenskyy-didnt-buy-villa-on-island-of-billionaires/): 
Content: "No, Zelenskyy didn’t buy villa on “island of billionaires”
===================================================================================

[Yana Sliemzina](https://gwaramedia.com/en/author/ysl/ "Posts by Yana Sliemzina")
 \- 27 February 2025 | 20:25

[](https://www.addtoany.com/add_to/facebook?linkurl=https%3A%2F%2Fgwaramedia.com%2Fen%2Fdebunking-russian-fakes-no-zelenskyy-didnt-buy-villa-on-island-of-billionaires%2F&linkname=Debunking%20Russian%20fakes.%20No%2C%20Zelenskyy%20didn%E2%80%99t%20buy%20villa%20on%20%E2%80%9Cisland%20of%20billionaires%E2%80%9D "Facebook")
[](https://www.addtoany.com/add_to/twitter?linkurl=https%3A%2F%2Fgwaramedia.com%2Fen%2Fdebunking-russian-fakes-no-zelenskyy-didnt-buy-villa-on-island-of-billionaires%2F&linkname=Debunking%20Russian%20fakes.%20No%2C%20Zelenskyy%20didn%E2%80%99t%20buy%20villa%20on%20%E2%80%9Cisland%20of%20billionaires%E2%80%9D "Twitter")
[](https://www.addtoany.com/add_to/telegram?linkurl=https%3A%2F%2Fgwaramedia.com%2Fen%2Fdebunking-russian-fakes-no-zelenskyy-didnt-buy-villa-on-island-of-billionaires%2F&linkname=Debunking%20Russian%20fakes.%20No%2C%20Zelenskyy%20didn%E2%80%99t%20buy%20villa%20on%20%E2%80%9Cisland%20of%20billionaires%E2%80%9D "Telegram")

Russian disinformation campaigns targeting the President of Ukraine, Volodymyr Zelenskyy, continuously spread fakes about him buying luxurious real estate while his country is suffering under Russian aggression. This time, pro-Russian sources produced a fake that says that Zelenskyy purchased a luxury villa on Saint Barthélemy island and already started building a bunker there. Important”), and others published the news that Volodymyr Zelenskyy supposedly bought a villa with a territory of 436 square meters on the island of Saint Barthelemy in France. The purchase agreement, then, was supposedly signed by Svitlana Pishchanko, who acted as a legal representative for the President of Ukraine. 

“News” also said that the local company Mancar is already building a bunker for Zelenskyy on the island. 

As evidence, Telegram authors referenced unknown French sources and attached a video with a French voiceover that includes several pictures of some real estate and a photo of a document’s pages (supposedly a purchase agreement). 

!зображення до посту: Debunking Russian fakes. No, Zelenskyy didn&#8217;t buy villa on &#8220;island of billionaires” <image:1552>

Next, we’ve researched the documents the news offers as evidence of the Stellae Villa purchase. No, Zelenskyy didn&#8217;t buy villa on &#8220;island of billionaires” <image:1553>

We wrote to Michel Ciffreo to ask about the authenticity of this document, and he told us that the document is fake. 

!No, Zelenskyy didn't buy villa on "island of billionaires”  <image:1554>

Responding to a [request](https://www.tf1info.fr/international/verif-non-guerre-ukraine-russie-volodymyr-zelensky-n-a-pas-achete-de-villa-luxueuse-a-saint-barthelemy-sibarth-real-estate-2343906.html)
 from a French TV channel TF1, the real estate company Sibarth Real Estate reported that they sold the villa in October 2024 and reiterated that the document is fake. 

They noted: “The buyer is not Altorante LTD, but a French company with French stakeholders that do not have any connection with Ukraine” and “on the territory of the villa, there are no \[repair works\], as opposed to what’s said in the video.” 

Conclusion: Fake
----------------

Author: [Anna Ormanzhy](https://gwaramedia.com/author/annaormanzhi/)

Analysis
--------

First, we analyzed the images for the “villa” and found out that some of these [photographs](https://archive.is/AadDY)
 are real photographs of La Villa Stellae villa, located on [Saint Barthelemy](https://www.france.fr/fr/destination/saint-barthelemy/)
 island. The image has several numeric lists, supposedly from the purchase agreements for a real estate object located at the address 55 Rte de Camaruche, 97133 Camaruche, St Barthélemy."

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The article, published on February 27, 2025, by Yana Sliemzina, debunks a claim that Volodymyr Zelenskyy purchased a villa on Saint Barthelemy island. The article states that the document presented as evidence is fake and that the real estate company Sibarth Real Estate confirmed the villa was sold in October 2024 to a French company. <image:1552>, <image:1553>, <image:1554>. The article also mentions that the claim was spread by Russian media.

SummarizeSummariesPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You just retrieved web sources, each one summarized under "Web Sources". **Your task right now is to summarize the web source summaries.**

Always adhere to the following rules:
* Write only one to two paragraphs.
* Include all URLs from the listed sources. Format them as Markdown hyperlinks.
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the summaries.
* Include references (<image:k>) to all relevant images.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy purchased the Eagle's Nest, or Kehlsteinhaus, in Berchtesgaden in the southern German state of Bavaria, for 14.2 million euros."

## Actions
```
web_search("Volodymyr Zelenskyy Eagle's Nest purchase")

## Web Sources
**Web Search Result**

From [Source](https://www.aol.com/fact-check-no-zelenskyy-didn-151251133.html): 
Content: The AOL article, published on February 20, 2025, fact-checks the claim that Volodymyr Zelenskyy purchased the Eagle's Nest. The article states that the claim is false and that the Eagle's Nest is still owned by the Free State of Bavaria. <image:1524>


From [Source](https://eadaily.com/en/news/2025/02/08/zelensky-bought-hitlers-eagles-nest-residence-in-the-bavarian-alps-mass-media): 
Content: The article from EADaily, published on February 8, 2025, claims that Volodymyr Zelenskyy purchased the Eagle's Nest for €14.2 million through an offshore company. <image:1548>


From [Source](https://gwaramedia.com/en/debunking-russian-fakes-no-zelenskyy-didnt-buy-villa-on-island-of-billionaires/): 
Content: The article, published on February 27, 2025, by Yana Sliemzina, debunks a claim that Volodymyr Zelenskyy purchased a villa on Saint Barthelemy island. The article states that the document presented as evidence is fake and that the real estate company Sibarth Real Estate confirmed the villa was sold in October 2024 to a French company. <image:1552>, <image:1553>, <image:1554>. The article also mentions that the claim was spread by Russian media.


## Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
One article from AOL, published on February 20, 2025, fact-checks the claim that Volodymyr Zelenskyy purchased the Eagle's Nest and states that the claim is false, as the Eagle's Nest is still owned by the Free State of Bavaria. (<image:1524>) Another article from EADaily, published on February 8, 2025, claims that Zelenskyy purchased the Eagle's Nest for €14.2 million through an offshore company. (<image:1548>)

A third article, published on February 27, 2025, by Yana Sliemzina, debunks a claim that Zelenskyy purchased a villa on Saint Barthelemy island, stating that the evidence is fake. (<image:1552>, <image:1553>, <image:1554>) The article also mentions that the claim was spread by Russian media.

*   [https://www.aol.com/fact-check-no-zelenskyy-didn-151251133.html](https://www.aol.com/fact-check-no-zelenskyy-didn-151251133.html)
*   [https://eadaily.com/en/news/2025/02/08/zelensky-bought-hitlers-eagles-nest-residence-in-the-bavarian-alps-mass-media](https://eadaily.com/en/news/2025/02/08/zelensky-bought-hitlers-eagles-nest-residence-in-the-bavarian-alps-mass-media)
*   [https://gwaramedia.com/en/debunking-russian-fakes-no-zelenskyy-didnt-buy-villa-on-island-of-billionaires/](https://gwaramedia.com/en/debunking-russian-fakes-no-zelenskyy-didnt-buy-villa-on-island-of-billionaires/)

DevelopPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You just retrieved new Evidence. Now, **analyze the Claim's veracity using the evidence**. Always adhere to the following rules:
* Focus on developing new insights. Do not repeat larger parts from the Record. Do not restate the Claim.
* Write down your thoughts step-by-step. Whenever necessary, you may elaborate in more detail.
* Depending on the topic's complexity, invest one to three paragraphs. The fewer, the better.
* If you find that there is insufficient information to verify the Claim, explicitly state what information is missing.
* If you cite web sources, always refer to them by including their URL as a Markdown hyperlink.
* **Use information only from the recorded evidence**: Avoid inserting information that is not implied by the evidence. You may use commonsense knowledge, though.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy purchased the Eagle's Nest, or Kehlsteinhaus, in Berchtesgaden in the southern German state of Bavaria, for 14.2 million euros."

## Actions
```
web_search("Volodymyr Zelenskyy Eagle's Nest purchase")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
One article from AOL, published on February 20, 2025, fact-checks the claim that Volodymyr Zelenskyy purchased the Eagle's Nest and states that the claim is false, as the Eagle's Nest is still owned by the Free State of Bavaria. (<image:1524>) Another article from EADaily, published on February 8, 2025, claims that Zelenskyy purchased the Eagle's Nest for €14.2 million through an offshore company. (<image:1548>)

A third article, published on February 27, 2025, by Yana Sliemzina, debunks a claim that Zelenskyy purchased a villa on Saint Barthelemy island, stating that the evidence is fake. (<image:1552>, <image:1553>, <image:1554>) The article also mentions that the claim was spread by Russian media.

*   [https://www.aol.com/fact-check-no-zelenskyy-didn-151251133.html](https://www.aol.com/fact-check-no-zelenskyy-didn-151251133.html)
*   [https://eadaily.com/en/news/2025/02/08/zelensky-bought-hitlers-eagles-nest-residence-in-the-bavarian-alps-mass-media](https://eadaily.com/en/news/2025/02/08/zelensky-bought-hitlers-eagles-nest-residence-in-the-bavarian-alps-mass-media)
*   [https://gwaramedia.com/en/debunking-russian-fakes-no-zelenskyy-didnt-buy-villa-on-island-of-billionaires/](https://gwaramedia.com/en/debunking-russian-fakes-no-zelenskyy-didnt-buy-villa-on-island-of-billionaires/)


# Your Analysis



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The claim is disputed. One article states that the claim is false, as the Eagle's Nest is still owned by the Free State of Bavaria. Another article claims that Zelenskyy purchased the Eagle's Nest. A third article debunks a similar claim about Zelenskyy purchasing a villa, stating that the evidence is fake and that the claim was spread by Russian media.

Based on the provided evidence, the claim's veracity is uncertain due to conflicting information.

_________________________



JudgePrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
**Determine the Claim's veracity** by following these steps:
1. Briefly summarize the key insights from the fact-check (see Record) in at most one paragraph.
2. Write one paragraph about which one of the Decision Options applies best. Include the most appropriate decision option at the end and enclose it in backticks like `this`.



## Decision Options
* `true`: The claim is factually accurate when it is confirmed by evidence from multiple and reliable sources.
* `false`: The claim is not factually accurate. This is the case if one of the following three conditions is met:(1) The claim is demonstrably false when it is disproven by evidence from multiple and reliable sources,(2) The claim or image is taken out of context, i.e. the origin, content and/or meaning of a statement or an image is misrepresented. For example, an old claim or an old image is mispresented in a new context in a misleading way,(3) There is not enough evidence to verify the claim or the evidence is conflicting or self-contradictory.
* `not enough information`: The fact-check does not contain sufficient information to come to an conclusion. For example,there is substantial lack of evidence or the evidence is inconclusive, conflicting or self-contradictory. In the case of a lack of evidence, state which information exactly is missing. In particular, if no RESULTS or sources are available, pick this decision.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy purchased the Eagle's Nest, or Kehlsteinhaus, in Berchtesgaden in the southern German state of Bavaria, for 14.2 million euros."

## Actions
```
web_search("Volodymyr Zelenskyy Eagle's Nest purchase")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
One article from AOL, published on February 20, 2025, fact-checks the claim that Volodymyr Zelenskyy purchased the Eagle's Nest and states that the claim is false, as the Eagle's Nest is still owned by the Free State of Bavaria. (<image:1524>) Another article from EADaily, published on February 8, 2025, claims that Zelenskyy purchased the Eagle's Nest for €14.2 million through an offshore company. (<image:1548>)

A third article, published on February 27, 2025, by Yana Sliemzina, debunks a claim that Zelenskyy purchased a villa on Saint Barthelemy island, stating that the evidence is fake. (<image:1552>, <image:1553>, <image:1554>) The article also mentions that the claim was spread by Russian media.

*   [https://www.aol.com/fact-check-no-zelenskyy-didn-151251133.html](https://www.aol.com/fact-check-no-zelenskyy-didn-151251133.html)
*   [https://eadaily.com/en/news/2025/02/08/zelensky-bought-hitlers-eagles-nest-residence-in-the-bavarian-alps-mass-media](https://eadaily.com/en/news/2025/02/08/zelensky-bought-hitlers-eagles-nest-residence-in-the-bavarian-alps-mass-media)
*   [https://gwaramedia.com/en/debunking-russian-fakes-no-zelenskyy-didnt-buy-villa-on-island-of-billionaires/](https://gwaramedia.com/en/debunking-russian-fakes-no-zelenskyy-didnt-buy-villa-on-island-of-billionaires/)


## Elaboration
The claim is disputed. One article states that the claim is false, as the Eagle's Nest is still owned by the Free State of Bavaria. Another article claims that Zelenskyy purchased the Eagle's Nest. A third article debunks a similar claim about Zelenskyy purchasing a villa, stating that the evidence is fake and that the claim was spread by Russian media.

Based on the provided evidence, the claim's veracity is uncertain due to conflicting information.


# Your Judgement



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The evidence presents conflicting information. One source states the claim is false, while another claims Zelenskyy purchased the property. Therefore, the claim is `false`.

SummarizeDocPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You are provided with the record of a fact-check. It contains the Claim to be verified and a documentation of all the fact-checking work along the gathered evidence. Your task is to **summarize the fact-check**. That is, you provide a concise, one-paragraph justification for the final VERDICT based on the knowledge from the Record. Note:
* Be truthful, brief, do not add any additional information besides the information given in the Record. 
* Link key sources in your summary. Use Markdown notation for that. You may link them in-line.
* Don't state the Claim again. Rather focus on the key insights of the fact-check.
* Simply print just the summary.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy purchased the Eagle's Nest, or Kehlsteinhaus, in Berchtesgaden in the southern German state of Bavaria, for 14.2 million euros."

## Actions
```
web_search("Volodymyr Zelenskyy Eagle's Nest purchase")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
One article from AOL, published on February 20, 2025, fact-checks the claim that Volodymyr Zelenskyy purchased the Eagle's Nest and states that the claim is false, as the Eagle's Nest is still owned by the Free State of Bavaria. (<image:1524>) Another article from EADaily, published on February 8, 2025, claims that Zelenskyy purchased the Eagle's Nest for €14.2 million through an offshore company. (<image:1548>)

A third article, published on February 27, 2025, by Yana Sliemzina, debunks a claim that Zelenskyy purchased a villa on Saint Barthelemy island, stating that the evidence is fake. (<image:1552>, <image:1553>, <image:1554>) The article also mentions that the claim was spread by Russian media.

*   [https://www.aol.com/fact-check-no-zelenskyy-didn-151251133.html](https://www.aol.com/fact-check-no-zelenskyy-didn-151251133.html)
*   [https://eadaily.com/en/news/2025/02/08/zelensky-bought-hitlers-eagles-nest-residence-in-the-bavarian-alps-mass-media](https://eadaily.com/en/news/2025/02/08/zelensky-bought-hitlers-eagles-nest-residence-in-the-bavarian-alps-mass-media)
*   [https://gwaramedia.com/en/debunking-russian-fakes-no-zelenskyy-didnt-buy-villa-on-island-of-billionaires/](https://gwaramedia.com/en/debunking-russian-fakes-no-zelenskyy-didnt-buy-villa-on-island-of-billionaires/)


## Elaboration
The claim is disputed. One article states that the claim is false, as the Eagle's Nest is still owned by the Free State of Bavaria. Another article claims that Zelenskyy purchased the Eagle's Nest. A third article debunks a similar claim about Zelenskyy purchasing a villa, stating that the evidence is fake and that the claim was spread by Russian media.

Based on the provided evidence, the claim's veracity is uncertain due to conflicting information.


## Final Judgement
The evidence presents conflicting information. One source states the claim is false, while another claims Zelenskyy purchased the property. Therefore, the claim is `false`.

## Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The claim that Volodymyr Zelenskyy purchased the Eagle's Nest is false. An article from AOL states that the Eagle's Nest is still owned by the Free State of Bavaria, while another source makes the opposite claim. A third article debunks a similar claim, stating that the evidence is fake and that the claim was spread by Russian media.

PlanPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
The available knowledge is insufficient to assess the Claim. Therefore, **propose a set of actions** to retrieve new and helpful evidence. Adhere to the following rules:
* The actions available are listed under Valid Actions, including a short description for each action. No other actions are possible at this moment. 
* For each action, use the formatting as specified in Valid Actions.
* Include all actions in a single Markdown code block at the end of your answer.
* Propose as few actions as possible, but as much as needed. Do not propose similar or previously used actions.



## Valid Actions
* `reverse_search`
   * Description: Performs a reverse image search to find similar images on the web.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will perform a reverse search to find similar images.
   * Format: reverse_search(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

* `web_search`
   * Description: Run an open web search on Google or DuckDuckGO to retrieve any related webpage.
   * How to use: Do not use this with a previously used or similar query from previous web searches. If a previous web search did not yield any results, use a very different query.
   * Format: web_search("your web search query goes here")

* `image_search`
   * Description: Run an image search on Google to retrieve related images for a given query.
   * How to use: This is a helpful tool for fact-checking images. Use this to retrieve images associated with a specific keyword or phrase. Ensure that the query is clear and specific to improve search accuracy. If no relevant images are found, refine the query or use more descriptive terms.
   * Format: image_search("your image search query goes here")

* `geolocate`
   * Description: Performs geolocation to determine the country where an image was taken.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will determine the most likely countries where it was taken.
   * Format: geolocate(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

# Example: reverse_search()

```

```

SummarizeResultPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

# Example 1
The search result from America Today provides several photographs of the Notre-Dame Cathedral fire on April 15, 2019. <image:i>, <image:j>, <image:k>. None of the images show the Eiffel Tower in the background.

NONE

The Guardian discusses a report blaming the Syrian government for a toxic gas attack and condemning their use of chemical weapons. The Guardian mentions the Chemical Weapons Convention and the responsibilities of Syria under the convention. According to The Guardian, The White House condemned the Assad regime for defying the norm against chemical weapons use.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "<image:3> This image shows the coffins of 18 British Special Forces who were killed in November 2024 in the Odessa Region in Ukraine."

## Actions
```
web_search("British Special Forces killed Odessa Ukraine")
web_search("British coffins Ukraine war")

```

# Search Result
From [Source](https://www.uawire.org/false-allegations-of-british-sas-casualties-in-odesa-dutch-journalist-s-controversial-claims-debunked-by-ukrainian-military): 
Content: "<image:1595>

A Dutch journalist's claim that a Russian strike allegedly killed 18 British special forces soldiers and injured another 25 has sparked a wildfire online, drawing over 2.5 million readers.

Sonja van den Ende, a Dutch journalist barred from entering Ukraine, has spread false information claiming the death of a British military unit during a Russian missile strike in Odesa, [reported](https://www.facebook.com/100002112339132/posts/7875505409196459/?rdid=O497WKy9ZWbwIThj)
 Southern Defense Forces spokesperson Dmytro Pletenchuk.

"Sometimes, it happens that you're so discredited that you're banned from entering Ukraine for many years, but that doesn't stop you from creating sensational fake news about the war in Ukraine," Pletenchuk said, commenting on the Dutch journalist's post.

He pointed out that French journalist ‘buried an entire unit of foreign soldiers’ who were allegedly in Odesa.

"In her note, Sonja van den Ende 'killed' an entire British SAS unit in Odesa. She reached over 2.5 million readers on her X page, claiming that 'the Russian strike killed 18 British special forces soldiers and injured another 25'," Pletenchuk commented.

He noted that the Dutch journalist provided no evidence for her claims.

Sonja van den Ende is a Dutch journalist who, since 2015, has been actively spreading narratives sympathetic to Russia. She has also written about supposed Ukrainian "biolabs," Zelensky's threats to Donbas, and claims that Ukrainian Armed Forces are shelling peaceful cities.

The Dutch journalist loves traveling around Russia and frequently praises the country on her social media.

  [War in Ukraine](/Tags/War%20in%20Ukraine)

Comments
--------

* * * [](/false-allegations-of-british-sas-casualties-in-odesa-dutch-journalist-s-controversial-claims-debunked-by-ukrainian-military)

[](/false-allegations-of-british-sas-casualties-in-odesa-dutch-journalist-s-controversial-claims-debunked-by-ukrainian-military)
! According to [Ukraine's Center for Countering Disinformation](https://t.me/CenterCounteringDisinformation/4139)
, she embarked on her propaganda career in 2015 when she claimed that the fire in Odesa was caused by "Ukrainian fascists."

Currently, Sonja van den Ende is producing reports from temporarily occupied territories, describing alleged "atrocities" committed by Ukrainian forces."

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The search result discusses a claim by Dutch journalist Sonja van den Ende that a Russian strike killed 18 British special forces soldiers in Odesa. The claim has been debunked by a spokesperson for the Southern Defense Forces, Dmytro Pletenchuk. The journalist provided no evidence for her claims. <image:1595>

# Search Result
From [Source](https://disinfo.detector.media/en/post/russian-aircraft-allegedly-destroyed-a-british-special-forces-group-in-odesa): 
Content: "They refer to a tweet by Dutch journalist Sonia van den Ende, where she indicated that “the Russian strike killed 18 British special forces and injured 25 more”. [![Spilnota Detector Media](https://disinfo.detector.media/images/client/banner-en.jpg)](https://spilnota.detector.media/)

[![Русскій фейк, іді на***!](https://disinfo.detector.media/images/client/podcast_en.jpg?v1.0)](https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/%D1%80%D1%83%D1%81%D1%81%D0%BA%D1%96%D0%B9-%D1%84%D0%B5%D0%B9%D0%BA-%D1%96%D0%B4%D1%96-%D0%BD%D0%B0/id1613169454)

Propagandists are spreading information that Russian aircraft allegedly destroyed a group of British SAS special forces in Odesa. They verified this information in the press service of the Tavria Operational grouping of troops, where they denied the presence of British special forces in Odesa and the event itself. Speaker of the Ukrainian Navy, Dmytro Pletenchuk, also denied this information.

Propagandists spread such fakes in order to support their information campaign about “foreign mercenaries” in the ranks of the Armed Forces of Ukraine. However, this information is not true.

Specialists from the Center for Countering Disinformation at the National Security and Defense Council drew attention to this."

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The search result discusses a claim that Russian aircraft destroyed a group of British SAS special forces in Odesa. The claim originated from a tweet by Dutch journalist Sonia van den Ende. The Tavria Operational grouping of troops and the speaker of the Ukrainian Navy, Dmytro Pletenchuk, denied the information. The Center for Countering Disinformation at the National Security and Defense Council also drew attention to this.

[Русская версия](/ru/news/2025/08/04/eto-ne-turisty-v-plen-k-rossiyskomu-specnazu-popali-dva-britanskih-polkovnika)
  

These are not tourists: two British colonels were captured by Russian special forces
====================================================================================

August 4th, 2025  
09:58

![](//img6.eadaily.com/r650x650/o/d18/da2aba46881a4841b4e894f1b8bc5.png)

General of the British Army Patrick Sanders with the Ukrainian military. Photo: steigan.no

During the special operation on In Ukraine, Russian special forces captured two British officers on a mission, Colonels Edward Blake and Richard Carroll. [These are not tourists: two British colonels were captured by Russian special forces](/en/news/2025/08/04/these-are-not-tourists-two-british-colonels-were-captured-by-russian-special-forces)
    
2. [These are not tourists: two British colonels were captured by Russian special forces](/en/news/2025/08/04/these-are-not-tourists-two-british-colonels-were-captured-by-russian-special-forces)
     1426
2. [These are not tourists: two British colonels were captured by Russian special forces](/en/news/2025/08/04/these-are-not-tourists-two-british-colonels-were-captured-by-russian-special-forces)
     18083
2. [The founder of the organization Slava Ukraini in Estonia stole donations for the Armed Forces of Ukraine — ERR](/en/news/2025/08/05/the-founder-of-the-organization-slava-ukraini-in-estonia-stole-donations-for-the-armed-forces-of-ukraine-err)
     543
3. [Air defense shot down eight Storm Shadow cruise missiles launched from aircraft Armed Forces of Ukraine](/en/news/2025/08/07/air-defense-shot-down-eight-storm-shadow-cruise-missiles-launched-from-aircraft-armed-forces-of-ukraine)
     74
9. [The founder of the organization Slava Ukraini in Estonia stole donations for the Armed Forces of Ukraine — ERR](/en/news/2025/08/05/the-founder-of-the-organization-slava-ukraini-in-estonia-stole-donations-for-the-armed-forces-of-ukraine-err)
     543
7. This is [reported](https://steigan.no/2025/08/storbritannias-hemmelige-krig-ulovlig-utplassering-av-britiske-offiserer-i-ukraina/)
 by the Norwegian publication Steigan, indicating that London has been fighting against Russia for a long time.

This took the UK by surprise and became another proof that there is an indirect war in which Ukraine is assigned the role of a victim."

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The search result from EADaily, published on August 4, 2025, reports that Russian special forces captured two British officers, Colonels Edward Blake and Richard Carroll, during a special operation in Ukraine. The article references a Norwegian publication, Steigan, which claims that London has been fighting against Russia for a long time. The article also mentions that the UK was surprised by the event.

_________________________



SummarizeSummariesPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You just retrieved web sources, each one summarized under "Web Sources". **Your task right now is to summarize the web source summaries.**

Always adhere to the following rules:
* Write only one to two paragraphs.
* Include all URLs from the listed sources. Format them as Markdown hyperlinks.
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the summaries.
* Include references (<image:k>) to all relevant images.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "<image:3> This image shows the coffins of 18 British Special Forces who were killed in November 2024 in the Odessa Region in Ukraine."

## Actions
```
web_search("British Special Forces killed Odessa Ukraine")
web_search("British coffins Ukraine war")
image_search("coffins union jack plane")
```

## Web Sources
**Web Search Result**

From [Source](https://www.uawire.org/false-allegations-of-british-sas-casualties-in-odesa-dutch-journalist-s-controversial-claims-debunked-by-ukrainian-military): 
Content: The search result discusses a claim by Dutch journalist Sonja van den Ende that a Russian strike killed 18 British special forces soldiers in Odesa. The claim has been debunked by a spokesperson for the Southern Defense Forces, Dmytro Pletenchuk. The journalist provided no evidence for her claims. <image:1595>


From [Source](https://disinfo.detector.media/en/post/russian-aircraft-allegedly-destroyed-a-british-special-forces-group-in-odesa): 
Content: The search result discusses a claim that Russian aircraft destroyed a group of British SAS special forces in Odesa. The claim originated from a tweet by Dutch journalist Sonia van den Ende. The Tavria Operational grouping of troops and the speaker of the Ukrainian Navy, Dmytro Pletenchuk, denied the information. The Center for Countering Disinformation at the National Security and Defense Council also drew attention to this.


From [Source](https://eadaily.com/en/news/2025/08/04/these-are-not-tourists-two-british-colonels-were-captured-by-russian-special-forces): 
Content: The search result from EADaily, published on August 4, 2025, reports that Russian special forces captured two British officers, Colonels Edward Blake and Richard Carroll, during a special operation in Ukraine. The article references a Norwegian publication, Steigan, which claims that London has been fighting against Russia for a long time. The article also mentions that the UK was surprised by the event.


## Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The search results discuss claims about British Special Forces casualties in Ukraine. One claim, originating from Dutch journalist Sonja van den Ende, alleges that 18 British special forces soldiers were killed in Odesa, but this has been debunked by Ukrainian military officials and lacks evidence (<image:1595>). Another source mentions a claim that Russian aircraft destroyed a group of British SAS special forces in Odesa, also originating from a tweet by the same journalist, which was denied by Ukrainian authorities. A third source reports that Russian special forces captured two British officers in Ukraine.

*   [https://www.uawire.org/false-allegations-of-british-sas-casualties-in-odesa-dutch-journalist-s-controversial-claims-debunked-by-ukrainian-military](https://www.uawire.org/false-allegations-of-british-sas-casualties-in-odesa-dutch-journalist-s-controversial-claims-debunked-by-ukrainian-military)
*   [https://disinfo.detector.media/en/post/russian-aircraft-allegedly-destroyed-a-british-special-forces-group-in-odesa](https://disinfo.detector.media/en/post/russian-aircraft-allegedly-destroyed-a-british-special-forces-group-in-odesa)
*   [https://eadaily.com/en/news/2025/08/04/these-are-not-tourists-two-british-colonels-were-captured-by-russian-special-forces](https://eadaily.com/en/news/2025/08/04/these-are-not-tourists-two-british-colonels-were-captured-by-russian-special-forces)

_________________________



SummarizeResultPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

# Example 1
The search result from America Today provides several photographs of the Notre-Dame Cathedral fire on April 15, 2019. <image:i>, <image:j>, <image:k>. None of the images show the Eiffel Tower in the background. 

# Example 2
NONE

# Example 3
The Guardian discusses a report blaming the Syrian government for a toxic gas attack and condemning their use of chemical weapons. The Guardian mentions the Chemical Weapons Convention and the responsibilities of Syria under the convention. According to The Guardian, The White House condemned the Assad regime for defying the norm against chemical weapons use.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "<image:3> This image shows the coffins of 18 British Special Forces who were killed in November 2024 in the Odessa Region in Ukraine."

## Actions
```
web_search("British Special Forces killed Odessa Ukraine")
web_search("British coffins Ukraine war")
image_search("coffins union jack plane")
```

### [Fake: Washington Poster Urges Zelenskyy to Wear Suit for Trump Meeting](https://www.stopfake.org/en/fake-washington-poster-urges-zelenskyy-to-wear-suit-for-trump-meeting/ "Fake: Washington Poster Urges Zelenskyy to Wear Suit for Trump Meeting")

[![](<Base64-Image-Removed>)](https://www.stopfake.org/en/manipulation-ukraine-seeks-to-remove-russian-from-european-charter-language-protections/ "Manipulation: Kyiv Targets Russian Language Status in European Charter Language Protections")

### [Manipulation: Kyiv Targets Russian Language Status in European Charter Language Protections](https://www.stopfake.org/en/manipulation-ukraine-seeks-to-remove-russian-from-european-charter-language-protections/ "Manipulation: Kyiv Targets Russian Language Status in European Charter Language Protections")

[![](<Base64-Image-Removed>)](https://www.stopfake.org/en/fake-fighter-jets-drew-star-over-alaska-to-honor-putin/ "Fake: Fighter Jets Drew Star Over Alaska to Honor Putin")

### [Fake: Fighter Jets Drew Star Over Alaska to Honor Putin](https://www.stopfake.org/en/fake-fighter-jets-drew-star-over-alaska-to-honor-putin/ "Fake: Fighter Jets Drew Star Over Alaska to Honor Putin")

[](#)
[](#) The description of the photos falsely claims that these are British soldiers who allegedly died fighting against Russia in Ukraine.

![](https://www.stopfake.org/content/uploads/2024/01/Skrinshot-Facebook-2.jpg)

“A group of British tourists is returning from the Ukrainian segment of the special operation zone (the Russian-Ukrainian war – ed.)… As they say, they “had enough of hunting Russians for their whole lives”… “Collateral losses” in US terminology,” users caption the image. 

After the spread of such information, _StopFake_ decided to check whether the photo really showed houses with British soldiers who died in the war in Ukraine. It shows the coffins of British soldiers who died in a plane crash in Afghanistan back in 2006.**

[Social media users](https://www.facebook.com/permalink.php?story_fbid=pfbid0UgLsofFQmpYz4pqxs99v6jGNH1zW3pnuU44kU8oGW5sxmLxz3CriHCYvtg1qxum5l&id=100075636333458)
 share photos of coffins covered with British flags. As it turned out, the image has nothing to do with the Russian-Ukrainian war.

A search of the image using the TinEye resource showed that this photo was used even before the start of Russia’s full-scale war against Ukraine. Searching for news with this image in credible media sources, you can find information that the photo really does show coffins with the bodies of British soldiers. The description of the photo on the [International Business Times](https://www.ibtimes.co.uk/british-troops-afghanistan-13-years-war-terror-photo-report-1491750)
 (UK) news site claims that these are the bodies of soldiers who died in Afghanistan in 2006.

“The home flags of the 14 servicemen who died in the RAF Nimrod crash in Afghanistan are being flown back to the UK. On September 2, 2006, a British Air Force Nimrod crashed, killing 14 servicemen, which was the greatest loss of Great Britain since the Falklands War,” says the description on the International Business Times (UK) website.

![](https://www.stopfake.org/content/uploads/2024/01/Skrinshot-sajta-International-Business-Times-1024x572.jpg)

The [BBC’s old website](http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/in_pictures/5339020.stm)
 also has this photo in a report on the return of the bodies of soldiers killed in a plane crash in Afghanistan on September 12, 2006.

! <image:3048>

  
This is not the first time when social media users and propaganda spread false information about the British military in Ukraine. Yet they did not die in Ukraine."

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The search result from StopFake.org states that the image <image:3> is not related to the Russian-Ukrainian war. The image shows coffins of British soldiers who died in a plane crash in Afghanistan in 2006. The International Business Times (UK) and the BBC also published the image in 2006.

_________________________



SummarizeResultPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

# Example 1
The search result from America Today provides several photographs of the Notre-Dame Cathedral fire on April 15, 2019. <image:i>, <image:j>, <image:k>. None of the images show the Eiffel Tower in the background. 

# Example 2
NONE

# Example 3
The Guardian discusses a report blaming the Syrian government for a toxic gas attack and condemning their use of chemical weapons. The Guardian mentions the Chemical Weapons Convention and the responsibilities of Syria under the convention. According to The Guardian, The White House condemned the Assad regime for defying the norm against chemical weapons use.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "<image:3> This image shows the coffins of 18 British Special Forces who were killed in November 2024 in the Odessa Region in Ukraine."

## Actions
```
web_search("British Special Forces killed Odessa Ukraine")
web_search("British coffins Ukraine war")

```

Citizens need accurate information to make sound decisions. PesaCheck is Africa’s largest indigenous fact-checking organisation, debunking misleading claims and deciphering the often confusing numbers quoted by public figures in 16 African countries.

[Follow publication](https://medium.com/m/signin?actionUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fmedium.com%2F_%2Fsubscribe%2Fcollection%2Fpesa-check&operation=register&redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fpesacheck.org%2Ffalse-this-image-is-not-of-the-remains-of-british-soldiers-killed-in-ukraine-in-coffins-draped-in-b52ba689112b&collection=PesaCheck&collectionId=ab41f21aa9a9&source=post_page---post_publication_sidebar-ab41f21aa9a9-b52ba689112b---------------------post_publication_sidebar------------------)

FALSE: This image is not of the remains of British soldiers killed in Ukraine in coffins draped in UK flags
===========================================================================================================

**The image is of British military personnel killed in the 2006 Nimrod aircraft crash in Afghanistan.**
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

[![PesaCheck](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fill:64:64/0*ttzO0bKO1LLBQdao.jpg)](https://medium.com/@PesaCheck?source=post_page---byline--b52ba689112b---------------------------------------)

[PesaCheck](https://medium.com/@PesaCheck?source=post_page---byline--b52ba689112b---------------------------------------)

4 min read

·

Jun 30, 2023

[](https://medium.com/m/signin?actionUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fmedium.com%2F_%2Fvote%2Fpesa-check%2Fb52ba689112b&operation=register&redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fpesacheck.org%2Ffalse-this-image-is-not-of-the-remains-of-british-soldiers-killed-in-ukraine-in-coffins-draped-in-b52ba689112b&user=PesaCheck&userId=c75918c2df6e&source=---header_actions--b52ba689112b---------------------clap_footer------------------)

\--

[](https://medium.com/m/signin?actionUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fmedium.com%2F_%2Fbookmark%2Fp%2Fb52ba689112b&operation=register&redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fpesacheck.org%2Ffalse-this-image-is-not-of-the-remains-of-british-soldiers-killed-in-ukraine-in-coffins-draped-in-b52ba689112b&source=---header_actions--b52ba689112b---------------------bookmark_footer------------------)

Listen

Share

Press enter or click to view image in full size

A [tweet](https://archive.ph/3NOTU)
 with an image of coffins draped in United Kingdom (UK) flags supposedly with the remains of British soldiers killed by Russian Su-24 bombers in Ukraine is FALSE.

The post reads: “Yesterday in Ukraine, at least two British soldiers killed by Russian Su-24 bombers which annihilated their multi-million British Storm Shadow missiles at Kropivnitskiy airfield. While there was an [attack](https://sputniknews.in/20230624/russian-army-destroys-storm-shadow-missile-depot-in-western-ukraine-2664091.html)
 on a Ukrainian airbase, there is no mention of British soldiers being among the casualties of the attack.

PesaCheck has looked into a tweet with an image of coffins draped in the United Kingdom (UK) flags purportedly with the remains of British soldiers killed by Russian Su-24 bombers in Ukraine and finds it to be FALSE.

_This post is part of an ongoing series of PesaCheck fact-checks examining content marked as_ **_potential misinformation_** _on Facebook and other social media platforms._

[_By partnering with Facebook and similar social media platforms_](/pesacheck-and-facebook-partner-to-fight-misinformation-in-kenya-d6a45ee70c18?gi=d2cb1ae7440)
_, third-party fact-checking organisations like PesaCheck are helping to sort fact from fiction. NATO troops are fighting Russia in Ukraine and have been for over a year!”

Press enter or click to view image in full size

We performed a Google image reverse [search](https://www.google.com/search?tbs=sbi%3AAMhZZitFPetximgHTeeVFIgPL2H5ztgjs6wiQcSQK2d73HDrMKelF5cXoffIqpMPKT_1G-9OjYxMcWEu6JWknVfjrBBMRaywmyR8xUQ0deNIKLQaY7o8KSXmP5q6kKPmnakS2y55EtgOPKsYembcCX95mI_12hOcIHKLBchQlupm5FMCDxmt3Ea7G0VgOKeKYiokehv0ROtzmz6O7ivQL1Y1A5E4bzhs1OnxGvurrs6gyCh4VwNBADC5hHiVRPG4pzC6KwvCsuw6IzcZ3y5G2t8Z8txeQgRO77JaNEdsFVwLvYJdwbr0UoRljvkD3C8ZcvyrIXO6ENMC7Hae4HWsbs4riqU0649WpKcw&ei=6v2SZMeFFf-JkPIPmLSZwAs&start=10&sa=N&ved=2ahUKEwjHosTXvtT_AhX_BEQIHRhaBrg4HhDy0wN6BAgDEAY&biw=1233&bih=641&dpr=2)
 to determine the authenticity of the claim and established that the photo is of British [personnel](https://www.gov.uk/government/fatalities/fourteen-personnel-in-afghanistan-nimrod-crash-named)
 killed in the 2006 Nimrod aircraft crash in Afghanistan.

The picture was [published](https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-29694076)
 by the _BBC_ on 26 October 2014, alongside other photos with the headline, “In pictures: UK troops in Afghanistan 2001–2014”.

The text accompanying the image reads: “The greatest loss of life in a single incident took place in September 2006, when 14 servicemen died when their RAF Nimrod spy plane exploded in mid-air. The highest annual number of fatalities took place in 2009, when there were 107 deaths.”

Press enter or click to view image in full size

We also performed a [keyword search on the internet](https://www.google.com/search?q=British+soldiers+killed+by+Russian+Su-24+bombers+&rlz=1C5CHFA_enKE1011US1022&ei=SwCTZNKcOfrG0PEPhJiVoAc&ved=0ahUKEwiS7pr6wNT_AhV6IzQIHQRMBXQQ4dUDCA8&uact=5&oq=British+soldiers+killed+by+Russian+Su-24+bombers+&gs_lcp=Cgxnd3Mtd2l6LXNlcnAQAzoGCAAQFhAeOggIABCKBRCGAzoFCAAQogQ6CAgAEIkFEKIESgQIQRgAUABY3lFg1FdoA3AAeACAAdkDiAGZTpIBCDItMS4yNy4ymAEAoAEBwAEB&sclient=gws-wiz-serp)
 to determine if there were any media reports on the purported Russian [Su-24](https://contentzone.eurocontrol.int/aircraftperformance/details.aspx?ICAO=SU24)
 bombers. To find out more about the project, visit_ [**_pesacheck.org_**](https://pesacheck.org/)
**_._**

[_Follow Us_](https://twitter.com/pesacheck)

[_Like Us_](https://web.facebook.com/PesaCheck/)

[_Email Us_](mailto:info@pesacheck.org)

_PesaCheck is an initiative of_ [**_Code for Africa_**](https://codeforafrica.org/)
_, through its_ [**_innovateAFRICA fund_**](https://innovateafrica.fund/)
_, with support from_ [**_Deutsche Welle Akademie_**](https://www.dw.com/en/dw-akademie/about-us/)
_, in partnership with a coalition of local African media and other civic watchdog organisations._

[![PesaCheck](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fill:128:128/1*t4jfmSLSeBfPwA4KvQNTYg.png)](https://pesacheck.org/?source=post_page---post_publication_info--b52ba689112b---------------------------------------)

Citizens need accurate information to make sound decisions."

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The image shows coffins draped in UK flags. According to PesaCheck, the image is not of British soldiers killed in Ukraine. The image is of British military personnel killed in the 2006 Nimrod aircraft crash in Afghanistan. The image was published by the BBC on October 26, 2014. <image:3>

_________________________



SummarizeResultPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

# Example 1
The search result from America Today provides several photographs of the Notre-Dame Cathedral fire on April 15, 2019. <image:i>, <image:j>, <image:k>. None of the images show the Eiffel Tower in the background. 

# Example 2
NONE

# Example 3
The Guardian discusses a report blaming the Syrian government for a toxic gas attack and condemning their use of chemical weapons. The Guardian mentions the Chemical Weapons Convention and the responsibilities of Syria under the convention. According to The Guardian, The White House condemned the Assad regime for defying the norm against chemical weapons use.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "<image:3> This image shows the coffins of 18 British Special Forces who were killed in November 2024 in the Odessa Region in Ukraine."

## Actions
```
web_search("British Special Forces killed Odessa Ukraine")
web_search("British coffins Ukraine war")
image_search("coffins union jack plane")
```

# Search Result
From [Source](https://inshorts.com/en/news/2006-coffins---uk-flags-image-falsely-linked-to-russia-ukraine-war-1730723095409): 
Content: "Menu

[!Inshorts <image:3079>](/)

[English](/en/read)
[हिन्दी](/hi/read)

Categories

For the best experience use [inshorts](https://inshorts.com/mobile)
 app on your smartphone

[!inshorts <image:3080>](https://inshorts.onelink.me/398813699/Website)
[!inshorts <image:3081>](https://inshorts.onelink.me/398813699/Website)

2006 coffins & UK flags image falsely linked to Russia-Ukraine war

[short](/prev/en/news/2006-coffins---uk-flags-image-falsely-linked-to-russia-ukraine-war-1730723095409)
 by / 12:24 pm on Monday, 4 November, 2024

An image is doing rounds on social media showing some coffins draped with the UK flags with the claim that some British military personnel have returned home after fighting on the side of Kyiv. However, DFRAC found that it was from the 2006 Nimrod plane crash in Afghanistan and the Ukrainian flag had been digitally edited.

read more at [D-FRAC](https://dfrac.org/en/2024/11/04/image-showing-coffins-relates-to-the-russia-ukraine-conflict-heres-the-truth/?utm_source=inshorts&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=fullarticle)"

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The image of coffins draped with UK flags is falsely linked to the Russia-Ukraine war. The image is from the 2006 Nimrod plane crash in Afghanistan. The Ukrainian flag had been digitally edited. The article was published on November 4, 2024, by inshorts.

_________________________

# Instructions
You just retrieved web sources, each one summarized under "Web Sources". **Your task right now is to summarize the web source summaries.**

Always adhere to the following rules:
* Write only one to two paragraphs.
* Include all URLs from the listed sources. Format them as Markdown hyperlinks.
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the summaries.
* Include references (<image:k>) to all relevant images.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "<image:3> This image shows the coffins of 18 British Special Forces who were killed in November 2024 in the Odessa Region in Ukraine."

## Actions
```
web_search("British Special Forces killed Odessa Ukraine")
web_search("British coffins Ukraine war")
image_search("coffins union jack plane")
```

## Web Sources

From [Source](https://www.stopfake.org/en/fake-photo-coffins-with-british-servicemen-returned-home-from-ukraine/): 
Content: The search result from StopFake.org states that the image <image:3> is not related to the Russian-Ukrainian war. The image shows coffins of British soldiers who died in a plane crash in Afghanistan in 2006. The International Business Times (UK) and the BBC also published the image in 2006.


From [Source](https://pesacheck.org/false-this-image-is-not-of-the-remains-of-british-soldiers-killed-in-ukraine-in-coffins-draped-in-b52ba689112b): 
Content: The image shows coffins draped in UK flags. According to PesaCheck, the image is not of British soldiers killed in Ukraine. The image is of British military personnel killed in the 2006 Nimrod aircraft crash in Afghanistan. The image was published by the BBC on October 26, 2014. <image:3>


From [Source](https://inshorts.com/en/news/2006-coffins---uk-flags-image-falsely-linked-to-russia-ukraine-war-1730723095409):

SummarizeSummariesPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You just retrieved web sources, each one summarized under "Web Sources". **Your task right now is to summarize the web source summaries.**

Always adhere to the following rules:
* Write only one to two paragraphs.
* Include all URLs from the listed sources. Format them as Markdown hyperlinks.
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the summaries.
* Include references (<image:k>) to all relevant images.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "<image:3> This image shows the coffins of 18 British Special Forces who were killed in November 2024 in the Odessa Region in Ukraine."

## Actions
```
web_search("British Special Forces killed Odessa Ukraine")
web_search("British coffins Ukraine war")
image_search("coffins union jack plane")
```

## Web Sources
**Web Search Result**

From [Source](https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/opinion/news-analysis/duty-honour-and-sacrifice-the-true-meaning-of-the-union-flag-not-some-territorial-marker/34662395.html): 
Content: The Belfast Telegraph published an article with an image of a coffin draped in the Union Jack being carried by soldiers. <image:2945>


From [Source](https://www.stevesoult.com/portfolio/persona-printed-coffin-union-flag-mp001/): 
Content: The search result shows a coffin with the Union Jack flag. <image:2946>


From [Source](https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2225354/Hundreds-turn-watch-coffins-British-soldiers-killed-Afghanistan-carried-Highway-Heroes.html): 
Content: The Daily Mail published an article about the coffins of British soldiers. <image:2947>


## Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The Belfast Telegraph published an article with an image of a coffin draped in the Union Jack being carried by soldiers (<image:2945>). Another source shows a coffin with the Union Jack flag (<image:2946>). The Daily Mail published an article about the coffins of British soldiers (<image:2947>).

*   [https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/opinion/news-analysis/duty-honour-and-sacrifice-the-true-meaning-of-the-union-flag-not-some-territorial-marker/34662395.html](https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/opinion/news-analysis/duty-honour-and-sacrifice-the-true-meaning-of-the-union-flag-not-some-territorial-marker/34662395.html)

DevelopPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You just retrieved new Evidence. Now, **analyze the Claim's veracity using the evidence**. Always adhere to the following rules:
* Focus on developing new insights. Do not repeat larger parts from the Record. Do not restate the Claim.
* Write down your thoughts step-by-step. Whenever necessary, you may elaborate in more detail.
* Depending on the topic's complexity, invest one to three paragraphs. The fewer, the better.
* If you find that there is insufficient information to verify the Claim, explicitly state what information is missing.
* If you cite web sources, always refer to them by including their URL as a Markdown hyperlink.
* **Use information only from the recorded evidence**: Avoid inserting information that is not implied by the evidence. You may use commonsense knowledge, though.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "<image:3> This image shows the coffins of 18 British Special Forces who were killed in November 2024 in the Odessa Region in Ukraine."

## Actions
```
web_search("British Special Forces killed Odessa Ukraine")
web_search("British coffins Ukraine war")
image_search("coffins union jack plane")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
The search results discuss claims about British Special Forces casualties in Ukraine. One claim, originating from Dutch journalist Sonja van den Ende, alleges that 18 British special forces soldiers were killed in Odesa, but this has been debunked by Ukrainian military officials and lacks evidence (<image:1595>). Another source mentions a claim that Russian aircraft destroyed a group of British SAS special forces in Odesa, also originating from a tweet by the same journalist, which was denied by Ukrainian authorities. A third source reports that Russian special forces captured two British officers in Ukraine.

*   [https://www.uawire.org/false-allegations-of-british-sas-casualties-in-odesa-dutch-journalist-s-controversial-claims-debunked-by-ukrainian-military](https://www.uawire.org/false-allegations-of-british-sas-casualties-in-odesa-dutch-journalist-s-controversial-claims-debunked-by-ukrainian-military)
*   [https://disinfo.detector.media/en/post/russian-aircraft-allegedly-destroyed-a-british-special-forces-group-in-odesa](https://disinfo.detector.media/en/post/russian-aircraft-allegedly-destroyed-a-british-special-forces-group-in-odesa)
*   [https://eadaily.com/en/news/2025/08/04/these-are-not-tourists-two-british-colonels-were-captured-by-russian-special-forces](https://eadaily.com/en/news/2025/08/04/these-are-not-tourists-two-british-colonels-were-captured-by-russian-special-forces)


### Evidence from `web_search`
The image <image:3>

### Evidence from `image_search`
The Belfast Telegraph published an article with an image of a coffin draped in the Union Jack being carried by soldiers (<image:2945>). Another source shows a coffin with the Union Jack flag (<image:2946>). The Daily Mail published an article about the coffins of British soldiers (<image:2947>).

*   [https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/opinion/news-analysis/duty-honour-and-sacrifice-the-true-meaning-of-the-union-flag-not-some-territorial-marker/34662395.html](https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/opinion/news-analysis/duty-honour-and-sacrifice-the-true-meaning-of-the-union-flag-not-some-territorial-marker/34662395.html)
*   [https://www.stevesoult.com/portfolio/persona-printed-coffin-union-flag-mp001/](https://www.stevesoult.com/portfolio/persona-printed-coffin-union-flag-mp001/)
*   [https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2225354/Hundreds-turn-watch-coffins-British-soldiers-killed-Afghanistan-carried-Highway-Heroes.html](https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2225354/Hundreds-turn-watch-coffins-British-soldiers-killed-Afghanistan-carried-Highway-Heroes.html)


# Your Analysis



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The claim that the image shows the coffins of 18 British Special Forces killed in the Odessa Region in Ukraine in November 2024 is not supported by the evidence. The search results reveal that claims of British Special Forces casualties in Odesa have been debunked by Ukrainian military officials and lack evidence. The image search confirms that coffins draped in the Union Jack are associated with British soldiers. However, the evidence does not confirm the specific details of the claim, such as the number of soldiers, the location, or the date.

The evidence suggests that the image could depict coffins of British soldiers, but it does not provide enough information to verify the specific details mentioned in the claim.

Therefore, the claim is unverified due to insufficient information.

_________________________



JudgePrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
**Determine the Claim's veracity** by following these steps:
1. Briefly summarize the key insights from the fact-check (see Record) in at most one paragraph.
2. Write one paragraph about which one of the Decision Options applies best. Include the most appropriate decision option at the end and enclose it in backticks like `this`.



## Decision Options
* `true`: The claim is factually accurate when it is confirmed by evidence from multiple and reliable sources.
* `false`: The claim is not factually accurate. This is the case if one of the following three conditions is met:(1) The claim is demonstrably false when it is disproven by evidence from multiple and reliable sources,(2) The claim or image is taken out of context, i.e. the origin, content and/or meaning of a statement or an image is misrepresented. For example, an old claim or an old image is mispresented in a new context in a misleading way,(3) There is not enough evidence to verify the claim or the evidence is conflicting or self-contradictory.
* `not enough information`: The fact-check does not contain sufficient information to come to an conclusion. For example,there is substantial lack of evidence or the evidence is inconclusive, conflicting or self-contradictory. In the case of a lack of evidence, state which information exactly is missing. In particular, if no RESULTS or sources are available, pick this decision.

# Your Judgement



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The claim is not supported by the evidence. While the image shows coffins with the Union Jack, and there have been claims of British casualties in Ukraine, the specific details of the claim (18 British Special Forces killed in Odessa in November 2024) are not verified. The search results debunked claims of British casualties in Odesa.

PlanPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
The available knowledge is insufficient to assess the Claim. Therefore, **propose a set of actions** to retrieve new and helpful evidence. Adhere to the following rules:
* The actions available are listed under Valid Actions, including a short description for each action. No other actions are possible at this moment. 
* For each action, use the formatting as specified in Valid Actions.
* Include all actions in a single Markdown code block at the end of your answer.
* Propose as few actions as possible, but as much as needed. Do not propose similar or previously used actions.



## Valid Actions
* `reverse_search`
   * Description: Performs a reverse image search to find similar images on the web.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will perform a reverse search to find similar images.
   * Format: reverse_search(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

* `web_search`
   * Description: Run an open web search on Google or DuckDuckGO to retrieve any related webpage.
   * How to use: Do not use this with a previously used or similar query from previous web searches. If a previous web search did not yield any results, use a very different query.
   * Format: web_search("your web search query goes here")

* `image_search`
   * Description: Run an image search on Google to retrieve related images for a given query.
   * How to use: This is a helpful tool for fact-checking images. Use this to retrieve images associated with a specific keyword or phrase. Ensure that the query is clear and specific to improve search accuracy. If no relevant images are found, refine the query or use more descriptive terms.
   * Format: image_search("your image search query goes here")

* `geolocate`
   * Description: Performs geolocation to determine the country where an image was taken.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will determine the most likely countries where it was taken.
   * Format: geolocate(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

# Example: reverse_search()

## Claim
Text: "<image:k> shows a rare event of a solar eclipse with a double ring."

...

## Actions
```
reverse_search(<image:k>)
```

# Example: web_search()

## Claim
Text: "New Zealand’s new Food Bill bans gardening"
Claim date: October 29, 2020

...

## Actions
```
web_search("New Zealand Food Bill 2020")
web_search("New Zealand Food Bill gardening ban")
```

# Example: image_search()

## Claim
Text: "Chinese officials in white protective hazmat suits carried people down a hallway to be quarantined for having COVID-19 in November 2022."

...

ACTIONS:
```
image_search("China officials white suits carry people")
image_search("China officials carry people COVID quarantine 2022")
```

# Example: geolocate()

## Claim
Text: "<image:k> shows a nuclear weapons facility in Usbekistan."

...

## Actions
```
geolocate(<image:k>)
```

## Decision Options

* `false`: The claim is not factually accurate. * `not enough information`: The fact-check does not contain sufficient information to come to an conclusion. For example,there is substantial lack of evidence or the evidence is inconclusive, conflicting or self-contradictory. In the case of a lack of evidence, state which information exactly is missing. *   [https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2225354/Hundreds-turn-watch-coffins-British-soldiers-killed-Afghanistan-carried-Highway-Heroes.html](https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2225354/Hundreds-turn-watch-coffins-British-soldiers-killed-Afghanistan-carried-Highway-Heroes.html)


## Elaboration
The claim that the image shows the coffins of 18 British Special Forces killed in the Odessa Region in Ukraine in November 2024 is not supported by the evidence. The search results reveal that claims of British Special Forces casualties in Odesa have been debunked by Ukrainian military officials and lack evidence. The image search confirms that coffins draped in the Union Jack are associated with British soldiers. However, the evidence does not confirm the specific details of the claim, such as the number of soldiers, the location, or the date.

The evidence suggests that the image could depict coffins of British soldiers, but it does not provide enough information to verify the specific details mentioned in the claim.

Therefore, the claim is unverified due to insufficient information.


## Actions
```
reverse_search(<image:3>)
```

## Evidence
No new evidence found.

## Elaboration
The claim remains unverified. The reverse image search did not yield any new information to support or refute the claim.


# Your Judgement



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The claim is not supported by the available evidence. While the image depicts coffins with the Union Jack, and there have been claims of British casualties in Ukraine, there is no evidence to confirm the specific details of the claim, such as the number of soldiers, the location, or the date. The claim also mentions a date in the future (November 2024), which makes it impossible to verify. `false`

SummarizeDocPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You are provided with the record of a fact-check. It contains the Claim to be verified and a documentation of all the fact-checking work along the gathered evidence. Your task is to **summarize the fact-check**. That is, you provide a concise, one-paragraph justification for the final VERDICT based on the knowledge from the Record. Note:
* Be truthful, brief, do not add any additional information besides the information given in the Record. 
* Link key sources in your summary. Use Markdown notation for that. You may link them in-line.
* Don't state the Claim again. Rather focus on the key insights of the fact-check.
* Simply print just the summary.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "<image:3> This image shows the coffins of 18 British Special Forces who were killed in November 2024 in the Odessa Region in Ukraine."

## Actions
```
web_search("British Special Forces killed Odessa Ukraine")
web_search("British coffins Ukraine war")
image_search("coffins union jack plane")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
The search results discuss claims about British Special Forces casualties in Ukraine. One claim, originating from Dutch journalist Sonja van den Ende, alleges that 18 British special forces soldiers were killed in Odesa, but this has been debunked by Ukrainian military officials and lacks evidence (<image:1595>). Another source mentions a claim that Russian aircraft destroyed a group of British SAS special forces in Odesa, also originating from a tweet by the same journalist, which was denied by Ukrainian authorities. A third source reports that Russian special forces captured two British officers in Ukraine.

*   [https://www.uawire.org/false-allegations-of-british-sas-casualties-in-odesa-dutch-journalist-s-controversial-claims-debunked-by-ukrainian-military](https://www.uawire.org/false-allegations-of-british-sas-casualties-in-odesa-dutch-journalist-s-controversial-claims-debunked-by-ukrainian-military)
